name: acetylpheneturide
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1196
Reason: 1,3-dioxolane has a melting point of around 100 degrees Celsius. The basic unit for this compound can be considered 1,3-dioxane, which has a melting point of around 100 degrees Celsius. The additional functional groups and structural features in acetylpheneturide will affect its melting point: (1) The acetyl group introduces a carbonyl functional group, which can increase the melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions, estimated at around +10 degrees Celsius. (2) The phenyl group introduces a rigid structure and additional molecular weight, estimated at around +20 degrees Celsius. (3) The ether linkage reduces the melting point due to the reduced molecular weight and the absence of hydrogen bonding potential, estimated at around -10 degrees Celsius. Summing these modifications gives us an estimated melting point shift.
